Question 1: What is the origin of the word "barbecue"? Options: A. From the word "barabicu" used by the Taíno people in the Caribbean islands, B. From the word "BBQ" used by the Germans, C. From the word "sacred fire pit" used by the ancient Greeks, D. From the word "smoke ring" used by the Americans Correct Option: A
Question 2: According to Aaron Franklin, what is BBQ? Options: A. Only grilling over a live fire, B. Only slow offset cooking, C. Anything cooked over a live fire, including grilling and slow offset cooking, D. Only cooking in the ground Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the Maillard reaction in cooking? Options: A. A process where proteins break down into amino acids and react with sugars to create a brown color, B. A process where collagen turns into gelatin, C. A process where fat melts and becomes liquid, D. A process where meat becomes tender and juicy Correct Option: A
Question 4: What type of tissue is abundant in brisket, making it challenging to cook? Options: A. Muscle tissue, B. Connective tissue, C. Fat tissue, D. Bone tissue Correct Option: B
Question 5: What happens to collagen when it is heated slowly over a long period? Options: A. It becomes tougher and more rubbery, B. It melts and turns into gelatin, C. It breaks down into amino acids, D. It becomes less tender Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the role of saturated fats in BBQ? Options: A. They have a low melting point and become liquid quickly, B. They have a high melting point and become liquid slowly, C. They are not important in BBQ, D. They make the meat less tender Correct Option: B
Question 7: How does the type of wood used in BBQ affect the flavor of the meat? Options: A. Different types of wood produce the same flavor, B. Different types of wood produce different flavors due to the cellulose and lignin content, C. Wood does not affect the flavor of the meat, D. Only hardwoods produce a good flavor Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the reason for the red color of the smoke ring in BBQ? Options: A. The presence of oxygen in the meat, B. The presence of carbon monoxide and nitric oxide in the smoke, C. The high temperature of the fire, D. The type of wood used Correct Option: B
Question 9: According to Aaron Franklin, what is the key to achieving good BBQ? Options: A. Following a recipe exactly, B. Using the right type of wood, C. Controlling the heat curve and guiding the meat to achieve the desired flavor, D. Using a thermometer to ensure the perfect temperature Correct Option: C

BBQ is a science that involves chemistry and physics, C. BBQ is a combination of art and science, D. BBQ is only about trial and error Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[♪ INTRO ♪] Parents have a bunch of catchphrases. Things like, “Don’t eat with your mouth
open” or “Don’t run with scissors." Another one you might recognize is “don’t sit too close to the TV; it’ll hurt your eyes." But it turns out that the science behind that one isn’t actually true—at least, not anymore. Your eyes might start to feel tired, but the
TV won’t actually hurt them. That idea came from some faulty televisions back in the late 1960s. About 50 years ago, General Electric accidentally released a line of color televisions that emitted X-rays from 10 to 100,000 times more than was considered safe. Talk about a manufacturing flaw. Like most other old, boxy TVs, the GE ones used cathode ray tubes, or CRTs, to generate a picture. Inside the glass vacuum tubes, electrons were fired at a screen covered in red, green, and blue phosphors, a type of material that glows when hit by something like electrons. And when fast-moving electrons strike something in a vacuum, it generates X-rays. To protect people from this radiation, engineers mixed lead into the glass ray tubes— but this batch of GE televisions was produced with faulty tubes. Two pieces were misaligned, which meant that the X-rays were deflected out of the bottom of the TV set and toward the ground right under
the television, where some kid was probably singing along to The Flintstones theme song. A recall notice estimated that sitting under the TV for a total of 40 hours would expose someone to so much radiation that their skin would turn red and painful. Which is... not great. But the good news is it doesn’t seem like
anyone was hurt. Thankfully, modern LCD TVs don’t emit harmful radiation at all, so you can sit as close as you want. But if you do spend too much time binging Netflix, you might still develop a headache. If you stare at the TV—or basically anything, including a book or your smartphone—for too long, you can tire out the muscles in and around your eyes and develop eye-strain. After a while, whatever you’re staring at
will start to get wobbly and fuzzy, and you might get a headache or feel tired. Fortunately there’s an easy fix: Go do something else, or at least just look away for a few seconds. Now, kids can focus on things close up much better than adults can without developing eye-strain, which is why they tend to get in the habit of sitting super close to screens—like televisions. And, in the 1960s, that might have been a
problem. But today, kids won’t get radiation burns
by doing it, no matter what their parents say. So the next time you’re in the mood for
a vintage movie marathon, you can sit wherever you’d like. But when Netflix asks you if you’re still
watching, it might be time to give your eyes a break. Thanks for asking, and thanks to all of our patrons on Patreon who keep the answers coming. If you’d like to submit a question to be
answered, you can go to patreon.com/scishow. [♪ OUTRO ♪]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Fifty years ago, General Electric accidentally released what kind of televisions?
Options: A. TVs that showed no color, B. Black and white TVs that emitted heat, C. Color TVs that emitted X-rays that were unsafe, D. TVs with plastic vacuum tubes
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the original reason behind the warning "don't sit too close to the TV; it'll hurt your eyes"? Options: A. The TV emitted too much blue light., B. The TV emitted X-rays due to a manufacturing flaw in some older models., C. The TV emitted too much sound., D. The TV emitted too much heat. Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which company accidentally released a line of color televisions that emitted excessive X-rays in the late 1960s? Options: A. Sony, B. General Electric, C. Samsung, D. LG Correct Option: B
Question 3: What type of material was used in cathode ray tubes (CRTs) to generate a picture? Options: A. Liquid crystals, B. Red, green, and blue phosphors, C. Plasma, D. OLED Correct Option: B
Question 4: According to the recall notice, what was the estimated effect of sitting under the faulty TV for 40 hours? Options: A. Skin would turn blue and numb., B. Skin would turn red and painful., C. Eyes would become permanently damaged., D. Hair would fall out. Correct Option: B
Question 5: Why do modern LCD TVs not pose the same risk as the faulty TVs from the 1960s? Options: A. They use more lead in their construction., B. They emit less X-rays due to better design., C. They do not emit harmful radiation at all., D. They are made with more glass. Correct Option: C
Question 6: What can happen if you stare at a screen for too long? Options: A. You will develop a permanent eye condition., B. You will become immune to eye-strain., C. You will tire out the muscles in and around your eyes and develop eye-strain., D. You will see more clearly. Correct Option: C
Question 7: Why do kids tend to sit closer to screens than adults? Options: A. They have better eyesight., B. They are more resistant to eye-strain., C. They can focus on things close up much better without developing eye-strain., D. They are more likely to develop eye problems. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is a simple way to alleviate eye-strain caused by staring at a screen? Options: A. Look away for a few seconds., B. Rub your eyes vigorously., C. Use eye drops., D. Wear glasses. Correct Option: A
Question 9: What might happen if you ignore the warning signs of eye-strain and continue staring at a screen? Options: A. You will develop a headache or feel tired., B. You will see more clearly., C. You will become immune to eye-strain., D. You will develop a permanent eye condition. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the main difference between the risks associated with sitting close to a TV in the 1960s versus today? Options: A. The risk of eye-strain is higher today., B. The risk of radiation burns is higher today., C. The risk of radiation burns was higher in the 1960s due to faulty TVs, but modern TVs do not pose this risk., D. The risk of eye-strain was higher in the 1960s. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (identifying the company responsible for releasing faulty TVs), options (company names), and content (specific reference to the late 1960s incident).

**Transcript**:
[♪ INTRO ♪] Parents have a bunch of catchphrases. Things like, “Don’t eat with your mouth
open” or “Don’t run with scissors." Another one you might recognize is “don’t sit too close to the TV; it’ll hurt your eyes." But it turns out that the science behind that one isn’t actually true—at least, not anymore. Your eyes might start to feel tired, but the
TV won’t actually hurt them. That idea came from some faulty televisions back in the late 1960s. About 50 years ago, General Electric accidentally released a line of color televisions that emitted X-rays from 10 to 100,000 times more than was considered safe. Talk about a manufacturing flaw. Like most other old, boxy TVs, the GE ones used cathode ray tubes, or CRTs, to generate a picture. Inside the glass vacuum tubes, electrons were fired at a screen covered in red, green, and blue phosphors, a type of material that glows when hit by something like electrons. And when fast-moving electrons strike something in a vacuum, it generates X-rays. To protect people from this radiation, engineers mixed lead into the glass ray tubes— but this batch of GE televisions was produced with faulty tubes. Two pieces were misaligned, which meant that the X-rays were deflected out of the bottom of the TV set and toward the ground right under
the television, where some kid was probably singing along to The Flintstones theme song. A recall notice estimated that sitting under the TV for a total of 40 hours would expose someone to so much radiation that their skin would turn red and painful. Which is... not great. But the good news is it doesn’t seem like
anyone was hurt. Thankfully, modern LCD TVs don’t emit harmful radiation at all, so you can sit as close as you want. But if you do spend too much time binging Netflix, you might still develop a headache. If you stare at the TV—or basically anything, including a book or your smartphone—for too long, you can tire out the muscles in and around your eyes and develop eye-strain. After a while, whatever you’re staring at
will start to get wobbly and fuzzy, and you might get a headache or feel tired. Fortunately there’s an easy fix: Go do something else, or at least just look away for a few seconds. Now, kids can focus on things close up much better than adults can without developing eye-strain, which is why they tend to get in the habit of sitting super close to screens—like televisions. And, in the 1960s, that might have been a
problem. But today, kids won’t get radiation burns
by doing it, no matter what their parents say. So the next time you’re in the mood for
a vintage movie marathon, you can sit wherever you’d like. But when Netflix asks you if you’re still
watching, it might be time to give your eyes a break. Thanks for asking, and thanks to all of our patrons on Patreon who keep the answers coming. If you’d like to submit a question to be
answered, you can go to patreon.com/scishow. [♪ OUTRO ♪]

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Here at SciShow HQ we have a little food area for the employees - Sometimes there are donuts. Sometimes there are nuts. Sometimes dried mango. But the one thing that never sticks around and is gone as soon as we can buy it is the wonderful, beautiful, noble banana. Unfortunately for us, they may not be around forever. [Intro Music] First, the good: bananas are healthy,
packed with nutrition and energy, they fit in your hand and give nice little
cues when they're perfectly ripe, and are easy to peel and eat; shocking statistic,
the banana is Wal-mart's number one selling item.
Not the potato chip, not Coca-Cola, not Fifty Shades of Grey, bananas. They
appear to be so perfect for human consumption that Kirk Cameron attempted
to use them to prove the existence of God. Of course this banana was not created by
God, or really even nature. Bananas, at least the ones that you see at the store, were created by people. Don't get me
wrong, there are wild banana plants - lots of them - they're native to South and
Southeast Asia, and there are dozens of species and
thousands of varieties. They're just not the ones we eat. Some
those species, as you might suspect, have seeds, 'cause that's what fruits
are, they're fleshy bodies containing seeds. So you might wonder, why have you never
eaten a banana seed? Well, you have... kinda. In cultivated bananas the
seeds have pretty much stopped existing. If you look closely you can see tiny black specks. Those are all that's
left, and they're not fertile seeds. If you
plant them, nothing grows. Today's bananas are sterile mutants. I'm
not trying to be mean, that's just the truth. Unless you were alive in the 1960's (hats off to all those older SciShow viewers out there) every banana you
have ever eaten was pretty much genetically identical. This is a Cavendish, the virtually seedless
variety that we all eat today, but it wasn't always our banana of choice. Until the
1960s, everyone was eating the same banana, it
was just a different banana - the Gros Michel, a bigger, sweeter fruit
with thicker skin. You might notice that banana flavored things don't really
taste like bananas. Well they do - they taste like the Gros Michel. The
genetic monotony of the Gros Michel crop was its undoing. A fungicide
resistant pathogen called the Panama disease began
infecting Gros Michel crop. By the time growers understood how
vulnerable their crops were, the Gros Michel variety was all but extinct. The entire banana industry had to be
retooled for the Cavendish. Since they're seedless, the only way to reproduce them
is to transplant part of the plant stem, and for the last 50 years we've been
good with the Cavendish, 'cause it's more resistant to the Panama
disease. However somewhat terrifyingly a strain of Panama disease that affects
the Cavendish strain that we all eat has been identified. A global monoculture of genetically
identical individuals is a beautiful sight to a pathogen. The fungus only has to figure out how to
infect and destroy a single individual, and suddenly there is no diversity to
stop it, or even slow it down. That's led to a lot
of scientists worrying about or even predicting the outright demise of the
Cavendish. This wonderful most popular of fruits might
completely cease existence. The good news is we now have a much better
understanding of genetics, epidemics, fungi, and pathology.
Scientists and growers have already taken steps to protect the Cavendish. Some growers are creating genetically
different bananas that might replace the Cavendish crop if it fails, while
scientists are attempting to genetically engineer Cavendish plants with immunity
to Panama disease. Plus we learned a lot from the Gros
Michel debacle. Infected fields are quickly being destroyed and new crops are
grown from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock. So thanks to the people who work
tirelessly to grow and harvest bananas and bring them to us so that we can offer them inexpensively
to our employees, and thanks to the growers and scientists working
tirelessly to make sure that they don't go the way of the Gros Michel. Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow, if
you have any questions, comments or suggestions for us, you can find us on
Facebook, Twitter or in the comments below, and if you want to
continue getting smarter this year at SciShow, you can go to YouTube.com/SciShow and subscribe. [banana eating noises] [music]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: 1. Wild banana plants are native to_____?
Options: A. South America, B. Southeast Asia, C. South Asia, D. both B and C
Correct Option: D

They have been genetically engineered to be seedless, D. They are sterile mutants and the seeds have stopped existing Correct Option: D
Question 3: What would happen if you were to plant the tiny black specks found in a cultivated banana? Options: A. A new banana plant would grow, B. A different type of fruit would grow, C. A fungus would grow, D. Nothing would grow Correct Option: D
Question 4: What led to the decline of the Gros Michel banana variety? Options: A. It was not as sweet as the Cavendish variety, B. It was not as resistant to disease as the Cavendish variety, C. A fungicide-resistant pathogen called the Panama disease infected the crop, D. It was not as widely available as the Cavendish variety Correct Option: C

Decreased risk of extinction, C. Increased genetic diversity, D. A pathogen only has to figure out how to infect and destroy a single individual Correct Option: D

Genetically engineering Cavendish plants with immunity to Panama disease, C. Destroying infected fields and growing new crops from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock, D. All of the above Correct Option: D

The Cavendish variety is more susceptible to the Panama disease, B. The Cavendish variety is less susceptible to the Panama disease, C. The Cavendish variety is completely resistant to the Panama disease, D. The Cavendish variety has a different susceptibility to a different strain of the Panama disease Correct Option: B

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not a direct match, but Question 2 has some relation to the origin of bananas. However, none of the generated MCQs directly ask about the native region of wild banana plants.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Here at SciShow HQ we have a little food area for the employees - Sometimes there are donuts. Sometimes there are nuts. Sometimes dried mango. But the one thing that never sticks around and is gone as soon as we can buy it is the wonderful, beautiful, noble banana. Unfortunately for us, they may not be around forever. [Intro Music] First, the good: bananas are healthy,
packed with nutrition and energy, they fit in your hand and give nice little
cues when they're perfectly ripe, and are easy to peel and eat; shocking statistic,
the banana is Wal-mart's number one selling item.
Not the potato chip, not Coca-Cola, not Fifty Shades of Grey, bananas. They
appear to be so perfect for human consumption that Kirk Cameron attempted
to use them to prove the existence of God. Of course this banana was not created by
God, or really even nature. Bananas, at least the ones that you see at the store, were created by people. Don't get me
wrong, there are wild banana plants - lots of them - they're native to South and
Southeast Asia, and there are dozens of species and
thousands of varieties. They're just not the ones we eat. Some
those species, as you might suspect, have seeds, 'cause that's what fruits
are, they're fleshy bodies containing seeds. So you might wonder, why have you never
eaten a banana seed? Well, you have... kinda. In cultivated bananas the
seeds have pretty much stopped existing. If you look closely you can see tiny black specks. Those are all that's
left, and they're not fertile seeds. If you
plant them, nothing grows. Today's bananas are sterile mutants. I'm
not trying to be mean, that's just the truth. Unless you were alive in the 1960's (hats off to all those older SciShow viewers out there) every banana you
have ever eaten was pretty much genetically identical. This is a Cavendish, the virtually seedless
variety that we all eat today, but it wasn't always our banana of choice. Until the
1960s, everyone was eating the same banana, it
was just a different banana - the Gros Michel, a bigger, sweeter fruit
with thicker skin. You might notice that banana flavored things don't really
taste like bananas. Well they do - they taste like the Gros Michel. The
genetic monotony of the Gros Michel crop was its undoing. A fungicide
resistant pathogen called the Panama disease began
infecting Gros Michel crop. By the time growers understood how
vulnerable their crops were, the Gros Michel variety was all but extinct. The entire banana industry had to be
retooled for the Cavendish. Since they're seedless, the only way to reproduce them
is to transplant part of the plant stem, and for the last 50 years we've been
good with the Cavendish, 'cause it's more resistant to the Panama
disease. However somewhat terrifyingly a strain of Panama disease that affects
the Cavendish strain that we all eat has been identified. A global monoculture of genetically
identical individuals is a beautiful sight to a pathogen. The fungus only has to figure out how to
infect and destroy a single individual, and suddenly there is no diversity to
stop it, or even slow it down. That's led to a lot
of scientists worrying about or even predicting the outright demise of the
Cavendish. This wonderful most popular of fruits might
completely cease existence. The good news is we now have a much better
understanding of genetics, epidemics, fungi, and pathology.
Scientists and growers have already taken steps to protect the Cavendish. Some growers are creating genetically
different bananas that might replace the Cavendish crop if it fails, while
scientists are attempting to genetically engineer Cavendish plants with immunity
to Panama disease. Plus we learned a lot from the Gros
Michel debacle. Infected fields are quickly being destroyed and new crops are
grown from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock. So thanks to the people who work
tirelessly to grow and harvest bananas and bring them to us so that we can offer them inexpensively
to our employees, and thanks to the growers and scientists working
tirelessly to make sure that they don't go the way of the Gros Michel. Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow, if
you have any questions, comments or suggestions for us, you can find us on
Facebook, Twitter or in the comments below, and if you want to
continue getting smarter this year at SciShow, you can go to YouTube.com/SciShow and subscribe. [banana eating noises] [music]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: 2. Fruits are fleshy bodies containing____
Options: A. no seeds, B. seeds
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the top-selling item at Walmart, according to the transcript? Options: A. Potato chips, B. Coca-Cola, C. Apples, D. Bananas Correct Option: D
Question 2: Why do cultivated bananas lack visible seeds? Options: A. They are harvested before they are ripe, B. They are a different species from wild bananas, C. They have been genetically engineered to be seedless, D. They are sterile mutants and the seeds have stopped existing Correct Option: D
Question 3: What would happen if you were to plant the tiny black specks found in a cultivated banana? Options: A. A new banana plant would grow, B. A different type of fruit would grow, C. A fungus would grow, D. Nothing would grow Correct Option: D
Question 4: What led to the decline of the Gros Michel banana variety? Options: A. It was not as sweet as the Cavendish variety, B. It was not as resistant to disease as the Cavendish variety, C. A fungicide-resistant pathogen called the Panama disease infected the crop, D. It was not as widely available as the Cavendish variety Correct Option: C
Question 5: How do growers reproduce the Cavendish banana variety? Options: A. By planting seeds, B. By using a fungicide, C. By cross-pollination, D. By transplanting part of the plant stem Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is a potential risk of having a global monoculture of genetically identical individuals, such as the Cavendish banana? Options: A. Increased resistance to disease, B. Decreased risk of extinction, C. Increased genetic diversity, D. A pathogen only has to figure out how to infect and destroy a single individual Correct Option: D
Question 7: What are scientists and growers doing to protect the Cavendish banana variety? Options: A. Creating genetically different bananas that might replace the Cavendish crop if it fails, B. Genetically engineering Cavendish plants with immunity to Panama disease, C. Destroying infected fields and growing new crops from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 8: How does the Cavendish banana variety compare to the Gros Michel variety in terms of susceptibility to the Panama disease that led to the decline of Gros Michel? Options: A. The Cavendish variety is more susceptible to the Panama disease, B. The Cavendish variety is less susceptible to the Panama disease, C. The Cavendish variety is completely resistant to the Panama disease, D. The Cavendish variety has a different susceptibility to a different strain of the Panama disease Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the main message of the transcript regarding the future of bananas? Options: A. Bananas will become extinct due to the Panama disease, B. The Cavendish banana variety will be replaced by a new variety, C. Scientists and growers are working to protect the Cavendish banana variety and ensure its continued existence, D. Bananas will no longer be a popular fruit Correct Option: C

Southeast Asia, and there are dozens of species and
thousands of varieties. They're just not the ones we eat. Some

Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. **Transcript**:
Here at SciShow HQ we have a little food area for the employees - Sometimes there are donuts. Sometimes there are nuts. Sometimes dried mango. But the one thing that never sticks around and is gone as soon as we can buy it is the wonderful, beautiful, noble banana. Unfortunately for us, they may not be around forever. [Intro Music] First, the good: bananas are healthy,
packed with nutrition and energy, they fit in your hand and give nice little
cues when they're perfectly ripe, and are easy to peel and eat; shocking statistic,
the banana is Wal-mart's number one selling item.
Not the potato chip, not Coca-Cola, not Fifty Shades of Grey, bananas. They
appear to be so perfect for human consumption that Kirk Cameron attempted
to use them to prove the existence of God. Of course this banana was not created by
God, or really even nature. Bananas, at least the ones that you see at the store, were created by people. Don't get me
wrong, there are wild banana plants - lots of them - they're native to South and
Southeast Asia, and there are dozens of species and
thousands of varieties. They're just not the ones we eat. Some
those species, as you might suspect, have seeds, 'cause that's what fruits
are, they're fleshy bodies containing seeds. So you might wonder, why have you never
eaten a banana seed? Well, you have... kinda. In cultivated bananas the
seeds have pretty much stopped existing. If you look closely you can see tiny black specks. Those are all that's
left, and they're not fertile seeds. If you
plant them, nothing grows. Today's bananas are sterile mutants. I'm
not trying to be mean, that's just the truth. Unless you were alive in the 1960's (hats off to all those older SciShow viewers out there) every banana you
have ever eaten was pretty much genetically identical. This is a Cavendish, the virtually seedless
variety that we all eat today, but it wasn't always our banana of choice. Until the
1960s, everyone was eating the same banana, it
was just a different banana - the Gros Michel, a bigger, sweeter fruit
with thicker skin. You might notice that banana flavored things don't really
taste like bananas. Well they do - they taste like the Gros Michel. The
genetic monotony of the Gros Michel crop was its undoing. A fungicide
resistant pathogen called the Panama disease began
infecting Gros Michel crop. By the time growers understood how
vulnerable their crops were, the Gros Michel variety was all but extinct. The entire banana industry had to be
retooled for the Cavendish. Since they're seedless, the only way to reproduce them
is to transplant part of the plant stem, and for the last 50 years we've been
good with the Cavendish, 'cause it's more resistant to the Panama
disease. However somewhat terrifyingly a strain of Panama disease that affects
the Cavendish strain that we all eat has been identified. A global monoculture of genetically
identical individuals is a beautiful sight to a pathogen. The fungus only has to figure out how to
infect and destroy a single individual, and suddenly there is no diversity to
stop it, or even slow it down. That's led to a lot
of scientists worrying about or even predicting the outright demise of the
Cavendish. This wonderful most popular of fruits might
completely cease existence. The good news is we now have a much better
understanding of genetics, epidemics, fungi, and pathology.
Scientists and growers have already taken steps to protect the Cavendish. Some growers are creating genetically
different bananas that might replace the Cavendish crop if it fails, while
scientists are attempting to genetically engineer Cavendish plants with immunity
to Panama disease. Plus we learned a lot from the Gros
Michel debacle. Infected fields are quickly being destroyed and new crops are
grown from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock. So thanks to the people who work
tirelessly to grow and harvest bananas and bring them to us so that we can offer them inexpensively
to our employees, and thanks to the growers and scientists working
tirelessly to make sure that they don't go the way of the Gros Michel. Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow, if
you have any questions, comments or suggestions for us, you can find us on
Facebook, Twitter or in the comments below, and if you want to
continue getting smarter this year at SciShow, you can go to YouTube.com/SciShow and subscribe. [banana eating noises] [music]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: 5. Why was the Gros Michel variety of banana so easily killed off by Panama disease?
Options: A. Panama disease was fungicide resistant, B. all Gros Michel bananas were genetically similar, C. the seeds of the Gros Michel bananas were infertile, D. both a and b
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the top-selling item at Walmart, according to the transcript? Options: A. Potato chips, B. Coca-Cola, C. Apples, D. Bananas Correct Option: D
Question 2: Why do cultivated bananas lack visible seeds? Options: A. They are harvested before they are ripe, B. They are a different species from wild bananas, C. They have been genetically engineered to be seedless, D. They are sterile mutants and the seeds have stopped existing Correct Option: D
Question 3: What would happen if you were to plant the tiny black specks found in a cultivated banana? Options: A. A new banana plant would grow, B. A different type of fruit would grow, C. A fungus would grow, D. Nothing would grow Correct Option: D
Question 4: What led to the decline of the Gros Michel banana variety? Options: A. It was not as sweet as the Cavendish variety, B. It was not as resistant to disease as the Cavendish variety, C. A fungicide-resistant pathogen called the Panama disease infected the crop, D. It was not as widely available as the Cavendish variety Correct Option: C
Question 5: How do growers reproduce the Cavendish banana variety? Options: A. By planting seeds, B. By using a fungicide, C. By cross-pollination, D. By transplanting part of the plant stem Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is a potential risk of having a global monoculture of genetically identical individuals, such as the Cavendish banana? Options: A. Increased resistance to disease, B. Decreased risk of extinction, C. Increased genetic diversity, D. A pathogen only has to figure out how to infect and destroy a single individual Correct Option: D
Question 7: What are scientists and growers doing to protect the Cavendish banana variety? Options: A. Creating genetically different bananas that might replace the Cavendish crop if it fails, B. Genetically engineering Cavendish plants with immunity to Panama disease, C. Destroying infected fields and growing new crops from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 8: How does the Cavendish banana variety compare to the Gros Michel variety in terms of susceptibility to the Panama disease that led to the decline of Gros Michel? Options: A. The Cavendish variety is more susceptible to the Panama disease, B. The Cavendish variety is less susceptible to the Panama disease, C. The Cavendish variety is completely resistant to the Panama disease, D. The Cavendish variety has a different susceptibility to a different strain of the Panama disease Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the main message of the transcript regarding the future of bananas? Options: A. Bananas will become extinct due to the Panama disease, B. The Cavendish banana variety will be replaced by a new variety, C. Scientists and growers are working to protect the Cavendish banana variety and ensure its continued existence, D. Bananas will no longer be a popular fruit Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 6 and Question 4. However, Question 6 does not address the Gros Michel variety, and Question 4 addresses the decline but not the genetic similarity. 

However, Question 8 addresses the susceptibility of the Cavendish and Gros Michel varieties to the Panama disease but does not directly address why the Gros Michel variety was easily killed off.

Considering all the options, Question 4 is the closest match, but it does not fully address the intent of the ground truth MCQ.

However, none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ. But if I had to choose one, I would say Question 4 is the closest match.

Index: 4

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Here at SciShow HQ we have a little food area for the employees - Sometimes there are donuts. Sometimes there are nuts. Sometimes dried mango. But the one thing that never sticks around and is gone as soon as we can buy it is the wonderful, beautiful, noble banana. Unfortunately for us, they may not be around forever. [Intro Music] First, the good: bananas are healthy,
packed with nutrition and energy, they fit in your hand and give nice little
cues when they're perfectly ripe, and are easy to peel and eat; shocking statistic,
the banana is Wal-mart's number one selling item.
Not the potato chip, not Coca-Cola, not Fifty Shades of Grey, bananas. They
appear to be so perfect for human consumption that Kirk Cameron attempted
to use them to prove the existence of God. Of course this banana was not created by
God, or really even nature. Bananas, at least the ones that you see at the store, were created by people. Don't get me
wrong, there are wild banana plants - lots of them - they're native to South and
Southeast Asia, and there are dozens of species and
thousands of varieties. They're just not the ones we eat. Some
those species, as you might suspect, have seeds, 'cause that's what fruits
are, they're fleshy bodies containing seeds. So you might wonder, why have you never
eaten a banana seed? Well, you have... kinda. In cultivated bananas the
seeds have pretty much stopped existing. If you look closely you can see tiny black specks. Those are all that's
left, and they're not fertile seeds. If you
plant them, nothing grows. Today's bananas are sterile mutants. I'm
not trying to be mean, that's just the truth. Unless you were alive in the 1960's (hats off to all those older SciShow viewers out there) every banana you
have ever eaten was pretty much genetically identical. This is a Cavendish, the virtually seedless
variety that we all eat today, but it wasn't always our banana of choice. Until the
1960s, everyone was eating the same banana, it
was just a different banana - the Gros Michel, a bigger, sweeter fruit
with thicker skin. You might notice that banana flavored things don't really
taste like bananas. Well they do - they taste like the Gros Michel. The
genetic monotony of the Gros Michel crop was its undoing. A fungicide
resistant pathogen called the Panama disease began
infecting Gros Michel crop. By the time growers understood how
vulnerable their crops were, the Gros Michel variety was all but extinct. The entire banana industry had to be
retooled for the Cavendish. Since they're seedless, the only way to reproduce them
is to transplant part of the plant stem, and for the last 50 years we've been
good with the Cavendish, 'cause it's more resistant to the Panama
disease. However somewhat terrifyingly a strain of Panama disease that affects
the Cavendish strain that we all eat has been identified. A global monoculture of genetically
identical individuals is a beautiful sight to a pathogen. The fungus only has to figure out how to
infect and destroy a single individual, and suddenly there is no diversity to
stop it, or even slow it down. That's led to a lot
of scientists worrying about or even predicting the outright demise of the
Cavendish. This wonderful most popular of fruits might
completely cease existence. The good news is we now have a much better
understanding of genetics, epidemics, fungi, and pathology.
Scientists and growers have already taken steps to protect the Cavendish. Some growers are creating genetically
different bananas that might replace the Cavendish crop if it fails, while
scientists are attempting to genetically engineer Cavendish plants with immunity
to Panama disease. Plus we learned a lot from the Gros
Michel debacle. Infected fields are quickly being destroyed and new crops are
grown from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock. So thanks to the people who work
tirelessly to grow and harvest bananas and bring them to us so that we can offer them inexpensively
to our employees, and thanks to the growers and scientists working
tirelessly to make sure that they don't go the way of the Gros Michel. Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow, if
you have any questions, comments or suggestions for us, you can find us on
Facebook, Twitter or in the comments below, and if you want to
continue getting smarter this year at SciShow, you can go to YouTube.com/SciShow and subscribe. [banana eating noises] [music]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: 1. Wild banana plants are native to_____?
Options: A. South America, B. Southeast Asia, C. South Asia, D. both B and C
Correct Option: D

Decreased risk of extinction, C. Increased genetic diversity, D. A pathogen only has to figure out how to infect and destroy a single individual Correct Option: D

Genetically engineering Cavendish plants with immunity to Panama disease, C. Destroying infected fields and growing new crops from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock, D. The Cavendish variety is more susceptible to the Panama disease, B. The Cavendish variety is less susceptible to the Panama disease, C. The Cavendish variety is completely resistant to the Panama disease, D. The Cavendish variety has a different susceptibility to a different strain of the Panama disease Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 7
Matching Prompt:

Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
Here at SciShow HQ we have a little food area for the employees - Sometimes there are donuts. Sometimes there are nuts. Sometimes dried mango. But the one thing that never sticks around and is gone as soon as we can buy it is the wonderful, beautiful, noble banana. Unfortunately for us, they may not be around forever. [Intro Music] First, the good: bananas are healthy,
packed with nutrition and energy, they fit in your hand and give nice little
cues when they're perfectly ripe, and are easy to peel and eat; shocking statistic,
the banana is Wal-mart's number one selling item.
Not the potato chip, not Coca-Cola, not Fifty Shades of Grey, bananas. They
appear to be so perfect for human consumption that Kirk Cameron attempted
to use them to prove the existence of God. Of course this banana was not created by
God, or really even nature. Bananas, at least the ones that you see at the store, were created by people. Don't get me
wrong, there are wild banana plants - lots of them - they're native to South and
Southeast Asia, and there are dozens of species and
thousands of varieties. They're just not the ones we eat. Some
those species, as you might suspect, have seeds, 'cause that's what fruits
are, they're fleshy bodies containing seeds. So you might wonder, why have you never
eaten a banana seed? Well, you have... kinda. In cultivated bananas the
seeds have pretty much stopped existing. If you look closely you can see tiny black specks. Those are all that's
left, and they're not fertile seeds. If you
plant them, nothing grows. Today's bananas are sterile mutants. I'm
not trying to be mean, that's just the truth. Unless you were alive in the 1960's (hats off to all those older SciShow viewers out there) every banana you
have ever eaten was pretty much genetically identical. This is a Cavendish, the virtually seedless
variety that we all eat today, but it wasn't always our banana of choice. Until the
1960s, everyone was eating the same banana, it
was just a different banana - the Gros Michel, a bigger, sweeter fruit
with thicker skin. You might notice that banana flavored things don't really
taste like bananas. Well they do - they taste like the Gros Michel. The
genetic monotony of the Gros Michel crop was its undoing. A fungicide
resistant pathogen called the Panama disease began
infecting Gros Michel crop. By the time growers understood how
vulnerable their crops were, the Gros Michel variety was all but extinct. The entire banana industry had to be
retooled for the Cavendish. Since they're seedless, the only way to reproduce them
is to transplant part of the plant stem, and for the last 50 years we've been
good with the Cavendish, 'cause it's more resistant to the Panama
disease. However somewhat terrifyingly a strain of Panama disease that affects
the Cavendish strain that we all eat has been identified. A global monoculture of genetically
identical individuals is a beautiful sight to a pathogen. The fungus only has to figure out how to
infect and destroy a single individual, and suddenly there is no diversity to
stop it, or even slow it down. That's led to a lot
of scientists worrying about or even predicting the outright demise of the
Cavendish. This wonderful most popular of fruits might
completely cease existence. The good news is we now have a much better
understanding of genetics, epidemics, fungi, and pathology.
Scientists and growers have already taken steps to protect the Cavendish. Some growers are creating genetically
different bananas that might replace the Cavendish crop if it fails, while
scientists are attempting to genetically engineer Cavendish plants with immunity
to Panama disease. Plus we learned a lot from the Gros
Michel debacle. Infected fields are quickly being destroyed and new crops are
grown from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock. So thanks to the people who work
tirelessly to grow and harvest bananas and bring them to us so that we can offer them inexpensively
to our employees, and thanks to the growers and scientists working
tirelessly to make sure that they don't go the way of the Gros Michel. Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow, if
you have any questions, comments or suggestions for us, you can find us on
Facebook, Twitter or in the comments below, and if you want to
continue getting smarter this year at SciShow, you can go to YouTube.com/SciShow and subscribe. [banana eating noises] [music]

good with the Cavendish, 'cause it's more resistant to the Panama
disease. However somewhat terrifyingly a strain of Panama disease that affects
the Cavendish strain that we all eat has been identified. A global monoculture of genetically
identical individuals is a beautiful sight to a pathogen. The fungus only has to figure out how to
infect and destroy a single individual, and suddenly there is no diversity to
stop it, or even slow it down. That's led to a lot
of scientists worrying about or even predicting the outright demise of the
Cavendish. This wonderful most popular of fruits might
completely cease existence. The good news is we now have a much better
understanding of genetics, epidemics, fungi, and pathology.
Scientists and growers have already taken steps to protect the Cavendish. Some growers are creating genetically
different bananas that might replace the Cavendish crop if it fails, while
scientists are attempting to genetically engineer Cavendish plants with immunity
to Panama disease. Plus we learned a lot from the Gros
Michel debacle. Infected fields are quickly being destroyed and new crops are
grown from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock. So thanks to the people who work
tirelessly to grow and harvest bananas and bring them to us so that we can offer them inexpensively
to our employees, and thanks to the growers and scientists working
tirelessly to make sure that they don't go the way of the Gros Michel. Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow, if
you have any questions, comments or suggestions for us, you can find us on
Facebook, Twitter or in the comments below, and if you want to
continue getting smarter this year at SciShow, you can go to YouTube.com/SciShow and subscribe. [banana eating noises] [music]

Correct Option: D

Question 3: What would happen if you were to plant the tiny black specks found in a cultivated banana? Options: A. A new banana plant would grow, B. A different type of fruit would grow, C. A fungus would grow, D. Nothing would grow Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 10

**Transcript**:
Here at SciShow HQ we have a little food area for the employees - Sometimes there are donuts. Sometimes there are nuts. Sometimes dried mango. But the one thing that never sticks around and is gone as soon as we can buy it is the wonderful, beautiful, noble banana. Unfortunately for us, they may not be around forever. [Intro Music] First, the good: bananas are healthy,
packed with nutrition and energy, they fit in your hand and give nice little
cues when they're perfectly ripe, and are easy to peel and eat; shocking statistic,
the banana is Wal-mart's number one selling item.
Not the potato chip, not Coca-Cola, not Fifty Shades of Grey, bananas. They
appear to be so perfect for human consumption that Kirk Cameron attempted
to use them to prove the existence of God. Of course this banana was not created by
God, or really even nature. Bananas, at least the ones that you see at the store, were created by people. Don't get me
wrong, there are wild banana plants - lots of them - they're native to South and
Southeast Asia, and there are dozens of species and
thousands of varieties. They're just not the ones we eat. Some
those species, as you might suspect, have seeds, 'cause that's what fruits
are, they're fleshy bodies containing seeds. So you might wonder, why have you never
eaten a banana seed? Well, you have... kinda. In cultivated bananas the
seeds have pretty much stopped existing. If you look closely you can see tiny black specks. Those are all that's
left, and they're not fertile seeds. If you
plant them, nothing grows. Today's bananas are sterile mutants. I'm
not trying to be mean, that's just the truth. Unless you were alive in the 1960's (hats off to all those older SciShow viewers out there) every banana you
have ever eaten was pretty much genetically identical. This is a Cavendish, the virtually seedless
variety that we all eat today, but it wasn't always our banana of choice. Until the
1960s, everyone was eating the same banana, it
was just a different banana - the Gros Michel, a bigger, sweeter fruit
with thicker skin. You might notice that banana flavored things don't really
taste like bananas. Well they do - they taste like the Gros Michel. The
genetic monotony of the Gros Michel crop was its undoing. A fungicide
resistant pathogen called the Panama disease began
infecting Gros Michel crop. By the time growers understood how
vulnerable their crops were, the Gros Michel variety was all but extinct. The entire banana industry had to be
retooled for the Cavendish. Since they're seedless, the only way to reproduce them
is to transplant part of the plant stem, and for the last 50 years we've been
good with the Cavendish, 'cause it's more resistant to the Panama
disease. However somewhat terrifyingly a strain of Panama disease that affects
the Cavendish strain that we all eat has been identified. A global monoculture of genetically
identical individuals is a beautiful sight to a pathogen. The fungus only has to figure out how to
infect and destroy a single individual, and suddenly there is no diversity to
stop it, or even slow it down. That's led to a lot
of scientists worrying about or even predicting the outright demise of the
Cavendish. This wonderful most popular of fruits might
completely cease existence. The good news is we now have a much better
understanding of genetics, epidemics, fungi, and pathology.
Scientists and growers have already taken steps to protect the Cavendish. Some growers are creating genetically
different bananas that might replace the Cavendish crop if it fails, while
scientists are attempting to genetically engineer Cavendish plants with immunity
to Panama disease. Plus we learned a lot from the Gros
Michel debacle. Infected fields are quickly being destroyed and new crops are
grown from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock. So thanks to the people who work
tirelessly to grow and harvest bananas and bring them to us so that we can offer them inexpensively
to our employees, and thanks to the growers and scientists working
tirelessly to make sure that they don't go the way of the Gros Michel. Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow, if
you have any questions, comments or suggestions for us, you can find us on
Facebook, Twitter or in the comments below, and if you want to
continue getting smarter this year at SciShow, you can go to YouTube.com/SciShow and subscribe. [banana eating noises] [music]

Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
there are 196 countries in the world
today and virtually none of them have purple on their national flag.
Throughout history, purple was never used to represent a kingdom civilization or
Empire. So what's wrong with purple? It's such a popular color today.
why would no country use it in their flag? the answer is really quite simple
purple was just far too expensive. No countries have purple on their flag
because up until the 1800s purple was worth more than its weight in gold
the color purple has been associated with royalty power and wealth for
centuries. In fact, Queen Elizabeth the first forbade anyone except close
members of the royal family to wear it. Purple's elite status stems from the
rarity and cost of the dye originally used to produce it the dye initially
used to make purple came from the Phoenician trading city of Tyre which is
now in modern-day Lebanon fabric traders obtained the dye from a small sea snail
that was only found in the tyre region of the Mediterranean a lot of work went
into producing the dye as more than 10,000 snails were needed to create just
one gram of tyree and purple since only wealthy rulers could afford to buy and
wear the color it became associated with the Imperial classes of Rome Egypt and
Persia purple also came to represent spirituality and holiness because the
ancient Emperor's kings and queens that wore the color were often thought of as
gods or descendants of the gods sometimes however the dye was too
expensive even for royalty third century Roman Emperor aurelion famously wouldn't
allow his wife to buy a shawl made from tyree and purple silk because it
literally cost three times its weight in gold
a single pound of dye cost three pounds of gold which is the equivalent of fifty
six thousand dollars today so since the sheer price of purple was so
astronomically high no one not
when the richest nations could afford to have purple on their flag the hue became
more accessible to lower-class is about a century and a half ago in 1856 18-year
old English chemist William Henry Perkin accidentally created a synthetic purple
compound while attempting to synthesize quinine an anti-malaria drug he noticed
that the compound could be used to dye fabrics so he patented the dye
manufactured it and got filthy rich purple dye was then mass-produced so
just about everybody could afford it the elite stopped valuing purple and the
status symbol faded away but the country flags remain the same since 1900 a
handful of new national flags have been designed and a few of them have opted to
use purple in their flag so don't be making any bets just yet hopefully you
found this interesting sometimes the simplest questions have the most
fascinating answers for more interesting videos like this one please subscribe

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The color purple did not represent which of the following:
Options: A. Holiness, B. Royalty, C. Spirituality, D. Generosity
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: How many countries are there in the world today, according to the transcript? Options: A. 150, B. 196, C. 200, D. 250 Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the primary reason why purple was not used in national flags throughout history? Options: A. It was considered an unlucky color, B. It was too expensive to produce, C. It was associated with a particular culture or region, D. It was not a popular color among monarchs Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the main challenge in producing purple dye from the Phoenician trading city of Tyre? Options: A. Obtaining the necessary equipment, B. Finding a market for the dye, C. Sourcing the rare sea snails needed to produce the dye, D. Competing with other traders Correct Option: C
Question 4: What can be inferred about the value of purple during ancient times based on its association with royalty and power? Options: A. Purple was valued for its aesthetic appeal, B. Purple was valued for its rarity and expense, C. Purple was valued for its spiritual significance, D. Purple was valued for its association with the lower classes Correct Option: B
Question 5: How did the discovery of synthetic purple by William Henry Perkin affect the value of purple as a status symbol? Options: A. It increased the value of purple as a status symbol, B. It decreased the value of purple as a status symbol, C. It had no effect on the value of purple as a status symbol, D. It led to a resurgence in the use of natural purple dye Correct Option: B
Question 6: Is purple still associated with royalty and power in modern times? Options: A. Yes, purple is still a symbol of royalty and power, B. No, purple is no longer associated with royalty and power, C. Purple is now associated with a different social class, D. The significance of purple varies depending on the culture Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the approximate cost of a single pound of Tyrian purple dye in ancient times? Options: A. Equivalent to $10,000 today, B. Equivalent to $56,000 today, C. Equivalent to $100,000 today, D. Equivalent to $1 million today Correct Option: B
Question 8: Why might some countries consider using purple in their national flags in the future? Options: A. Because purple is a popular color among young people, B. Because the cost of producing purple dye has decreased significantly, C. Because purple is no longer associated with royalty and power, D. Because some countries want to differentiate themselves from others Correct Option: D
Question 9: Which Roman Emperor refused to allow his wife to buy a shawl made from Tyrian purple silk due to its high cost? Options: A. Augustus, B. Aurelian, C. Julius Caesar, D. Nero Correct Option: B
Question 10: What was William Henry Perkin attempting to synthesize when he accidentally discovered the synthetic purple compound? Options: A. A new type of fabric, B. A dye for cotton, C. Quinine, an anti-malaria drug, D. A pigment for paint Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

However, it's worth noting that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent and options. But among the available options, Question 4 is the most similar.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 23, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
This is the Guimaras oil spill of 2006 and
it's the worst of its kind in the Philippine's history. More than 130
thousand gallons of bunker oil gushed into the Panay Gulf. In an attempt to contain the spill locals turn to an unconventional method: these
freaky-looking sausage things are all filled with synthetic materials
fabricated in a lab. It's also organic stuff you can find on most continents
and probably in your shower drain. It's human hair. After the Exxon Valdez oil
spill in Alaska Phil McCroy, a hair stylist in Alabama, had a novel idea for
the cleanup effort. On TV he noticed how a sea otter's fur had become saturated with
oil and thought if that's what oil would do to an otter's fur, then the same must
be true for human hair. He took scraps of hair trimmings from
work, stuffed them into his wife's pantyhose and tested his new invention
in a small spill he created at his house. NASA's studied and confirmed Phil's
invention worked. I called every hair stylist in Alabama 'til I found him. He said that his garage was full of hair being donated from salons all over the
place, but he'd never been able to make a business out of it and so from like
about 2000, 2001 we were partners. They teamed up on the Clean Wave program. It
collects donated hair, fur, feathers, and other fibers to make recycled felted
mats and hair booms that can mop up oil spills. Turns out hair is pretty good at cleaning up oil. It repels water and can
collect contaminants. Water goes into a sponge and it blows up and that's called
absorbent but oil coats hair on the outside so like it's called adsorbent. Hair is also natural, cheap, and renewable which makes it an ideal material for
cleaning up oil spills. Making a hair boom is pretty straightforward. All you need is human hair and pantyhose. Take the hair, stuff it into the hose, and
voilà. After getting over the freaky feeling of
handling someone else's clumped up hair, place it into contaminated water and
watch the hair boom do its thing. There's little diesel spills all the
time, so like every little harbor can use that stuff. You know, it was a great way
to just kind of string from dock to dock and kind of protect your private beaches. But hair booms and hair mats haven't been the principal method to clean major
oil spills. They weren't used extensively in the aftermath of the Deepwater
Horizon spill, where over the course of 87 days 134 million gallons of oil
gushed into the Gulf of Mexico. Instead, crews used 1.8 million gallons of
chemical dispersants, oil skimmers, fire, and booms and barriers made of synthetic
material to clean up the mess. With oil spills, time is of the essence. The longer oil is in the ocean the harder it is to retrieve. The immediate
ecological impact of oil spills is obvious. It kills marine wildlife and
destroys habitats and breeding grounds. The chemicals used to clean up oil
spills also pose a danger to human health. As of now, hair booms and hair
mats are not the primary tools used to contain oil spills, but possibly one day
they could be. It was very interesting for us to see the public desire to help. There's so many hair salons in every city and billions more people
with hair to spare. So it's not out of the realm of possibilities that help for
the next oil spill maybe just one snip away.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What happens to an organism's fur when exposed to oil?
Options: A. there is little or no effect, B. the fur of the organism usually repels the oil, C. it often becomes saturated with oil, D. organisms typically are unaffected by oil spills
Correct Option: C

Question 5: What are some benefits of using human hair to clean up oil spills? Options: A. It is expensive, non-renewable, and ineffective., B. It is natural, cheap, and renewable., C. It is synthetic, expensive, and renewable., D. It is natural, expensive, and non-renewable. Correct Option: B
Question 6: How are hair booms made, and what materials are needed? Options: A. Hair booms are made by stuffing human hair into pantyhose., B. Hair booms are made by mixing human hair with synthetic materials., C. Hair booms are made by weaving human hair into a mat., D. Hair booms are made by gluing human hair onto a surface. Correct Option: A
Question 7: Why weren't hair booms and hair mats used extensively in the aftermath of the Deepwater Horizon spill? Options: A. They were not effective in cleaning up large amounts of oil., B. They were not available in sufficient quantities., C. Crews used other methods, such as chemical dispersants and oil skimmers, to clean up the spill., D. They were not approved by regulatory agencies. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What are some of the immediate ecological impacts of oil spills? Options: A. They create new habitats for marine wildlife., B. They increase the population of marine wildlife., C. They kill marine wildlife and destroy habitats and breeding grounds., D. They have no impact on the environment. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is a potential advantage of using hair booms and hair mats to clean up oil spills in the future? Options: A. They are expensive and non-renewable., B. They are widely available and can be made from donated hair, making them a potentially scalable solution., C. They are only effective in small-scale oil spills., D. They are not effective in cleaning up oil spills. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the main idea of the transcript, and what message does it convey? Options: A. The transcript discusses the effectiveness of chemical dispersants in cleaning up oil spills and conveys the message that they are the best solution., B. The transcript discusses the potential of using human hair to clean up oil spills and conveys the message that it is a promising solution worth exploring further., C. The transcript discusses the impact of oil spills on the environment and conveys the message that they are not a significant problem., D. The transcript discusses the role of government agencies in responding to oil spills and conveys the message that they are doing enough. Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 23, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
This is the Guimaras oil spill of 2006 and
it's the worst of its kind in the Philippine's history. More than 130
thousand gallons of bunker oil gushed into the Panay Gulf. In an attempt to contain the spill locals turn to an unconventional method: these
freaky-looking sausage things are all filled with synthetic materials
fabricated in a lab. It's also organic stuff you can find on most continents
and probably in your shower drain. It's human hair. After the Exxon Valdez oil
spill in Alaska Phil McCroy, a hair stylist in Alabama, had a novel idea for
the cleanup effort. On TV he noticed how a sea otter's fur had become saturated with
oil and thought if that's what oil would do to an otter's fur, then the same must
be true for human hair. He took scraps of hair trimmings from
work, stuffed them into his wife's pantyhose and tested his new invention
in a small spill he created at his house. NASA's studied and confirmed Phil's
invention worked. I called every hair stylist in Alabama 'til I found him. He said that his garage was full of hair being donated from salons all over the
place, but he'd never been able to make a business out of it and so from like
about 2000, 2001 we were partners. They teamed up on the Clean Wave program. It
collects donated hair, fur, feathers, and other fibers to make recycled felted
mats and hair booms that can mop up oil spills. Turns out hair is pretty good at cleaning up oil. It repels water and can
collect contaminants. Water goes into a sponge and it blows up and that's called
absorbent but oil coats hair on the outside so like it's called adsorbent. Hair is also natural, cheap, and renewable which makes it an ideal material for
cleaning up oil spills. Making a hair boom is pretty straightforward. All you need is human hair and pantyhose. Take the hair, stuff it into the hose, and
voilà. After getting over the freaky feeling of
handling someone else's clumped up hair, place it into contaminated water and
watch the hair boom do its thing. There's little diesel spills all the
time, so like every little harbor can use that stuff. You know, it was a great way
to just kind of string from dock to dock and kind of protect your private beaches. But hair booms and hair mats haven't been the principal method to clean major
oil spills. They weren't used extensively in the aftermath of the Deepwater
Horizon spill, where over the course of 87 days 134 million gallons of oil
gushed into the Gulf of Mexico. Instead, crews used 1.8 million gallons of
chemical dispersants, oil skimmers, fire, and booms and barriers made of synthetic
material to clean up the mess. With oil spills, time is of the essence. The longer oil is in the ocean the harder it is to retrieve. The immediate
ecological impact of oil spills is obvious. It kills marine wildlife and
destroys habitats and breeding grounds. The chemicals used to clean up oil
spills also pose a danger to human health. As of now, hair booms and hair
mats are not the primary tools used to contain oil spills, but possibly one day
they could be. It was very interesting for us to see the public desire to help. There's so many hair salons in every city and billions more people
with hair to spare. So it's not out of the realm of possibilities that help for
the next oil spill maybe just one snip away.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Phil McCrory further developed his "hair raising" theory on oil spill cleanup with the help of what equipment?
Options: A. socks, B. human hair, C. pantyhose, D. b and c only, E. all of the above are great answers
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 23, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
This is the Guimaras oil spill of 2006 and
it's the worst of its kind in the Philippine's history. More than 130
thousand gallons of bunker oil gushed into the Panay Gulf. In an attempt to contain the spill locals turn to an unconventional method: these
freaky-looking sausage things are all filled with synthetic materials
fabricated in a lab. It's also organic stuff you can find on most continents
and probably in your shower drain. It's human hair. After the Exxon Valdez oil
spill in Alaska Phil McCroy, a hair stylist in Alabama, had a novel idea for
the cleanup effort. On TV he noticed how a sea otter's fur had become saturated with
oil and thought if that's what oil would do to an otter's fur, then the same must
be true for human hair. He took scraps of hair trimmings from
work, stuffed them into his wife's pantyhose and tested his new invention
in a small spill he created at his house. NASA's studied and confirmed Phil's
invention worked. I called every hair stylist in Alabama 'til I found him. He said that his garage was full of hair being donated from salons all over the
place, but he'd never been able to make a business out of it and so from like
about 2000, 2001 we were partners. They teamed up on the Clean Wave program. It
collects donated hair, fur, feathers, and other fibers to make recycled felted
mats and hair booms that can mop up oil spills. Turns out hair is pretty good at cleaning up oil. It repels water and can
collect contaminants. Water goes into a sponge and it blows up and that's called
absorbent but oil coats hair on the outside so like it's called adsorbent. Hair is also natural, cheap, and renewable which makes it an ideal material for
cleaning up oil spills. Making a hair boom is pretty straightforward. All you need is human hair and pantyhose. Take the hair, stuff it into the hose, and
voilà. After getting over the freaky feeling of
handling someone else's clumped up hair, place it into contaminated water and
watch the hair boom do its thing. There's little diesel spills all the
time, so like every little harbor can use that stuff. You know, it was a great way
to just kind of string from dock to dock and kind of protect your private beaches. But hair booms and hair mats haven't been the principal method to clean major
oil spills. They weren't used extensively in the aftermath of the Deepwater
Horizon spill, where over the course of 87 days 134 million gallons of oil
gushed into the Gulf of Mexico. Instead, crews used 1.8 million gallons of
chemical dispersants, oil skimmers, fire, and booms and barriers made of synthetic
material to clean up the mess. With oil spills, time is of the essence. The longer oil is in the ocean the harder it is to retrieve. The immediate
ecological impact of oil spills is obvious. It kills marine wildlife and
destroys habitats and breeding grounds. The chemicals used to clean up oil
spills also pose a danger to human health. As of now, hair booms and hair
mats are not the primary tools used to contain oil spills, but possibly one day
they could be. It was very interesting for us to see the public desire to help. There's so many hair salons in every city and billions more people
with hair to spare. So it's not out of the realm of possibilities that help for
the next oil spill maybe just one snip away.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What does the Clean Wave program collect to make their oil booms?
Options: A. feathers, B. human hair, C. pet hair, D. all of the above
Correct Option: D

This is the Guimaras oil spill of 2006 and
it's the worst of its kind in the Philippine's history. More than 130

freaky-looking sausage things are all filled with synthetic materials

collects donated hair, fur, feathers, and other fibers to make recycled felted
mats and hair booms that can mop up oil spills. Turns out hair is pretty good at cleaning up oil. It repels water and can
collect contaminants. Water goes into a sponge and it blows up and that's called

cleaning up oil spills. Making a hair boom is pretty straightforward. All you need is human hair and pantyhose. Take the hair, stuff it into the hose, and

Question: Hair is great at cleaning up oil due to the fact it is HYDROPHOBIC and BIOSORBENT. What do these two capitalized words mean?
Options: A. it removes substances and it attracts water, B. it repels water and removes substances, C. it attracts water and removes substances, D. it repels both water and other substances
Correct Option: B
